ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Korean language skills, including vocab, grammar, cultural contexts, even historical/linguistic roots of some words which was really interesting!
Improved speaking, reading/writing, and listening in Korean
I continued to develop my knowledge of the Korean language. Great for learning new grammar structures and about Korean culture!
This course covered more vocabulary, expressions, and grammar in Korean to supplement those learned in L1 and L2.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Instruction mostly in Korean; had trouble at first, but felt like it helped me improve a lot later in the semester
Weakness - Having more regular homework/vocab quizzes might have helped me remember the content a little better.
The class was fantastic! Good balance of slides to learn new content as well as practicing the language with classmates.

This was a very solid language course overall. It was interesting to learn new grammar and vocabulary every day as we worked through the modules of the textbook, and the class atmosphere was always relaxed and pressure-free, which made learning more fun.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It is a fun learning environment.

Yes! Korean is such an interesting language, and I've always felt like the instructors in the department are very kind and invested in helping students learn/improve. 130 in particular taught me a lot of grammar that I'd hear often from native speakers but didn't understand at the beginning of the semester.
Yes, fun class and develops Korean language skills

Yes, I really love the Korean language department at Yale, and I think KREN 130 is just as good as 110 and 120 (if not better). If you have a sincere interest in learning Korean, you can gain a lot from this course without having to stress about a heavy workload, strict professors, or impossible exams.
